Use the following scale to choose the most appropriate number for each situation

Insomnia is charaacterized by difficulty falling and/or staying asleep,usually associated withy daytime symptoms such as mental fogginess or fatigue. 30% of the population suffers from insomnia at some point, and for about 1 in 10people insomnia is a persistent problem. Sleep studies are not usually needed to diagnose insomnia, but may be ordered if another sleep disorder is suspected, like sleep apnea.

The main treatment for insomnia is changing the way you think or behave around your sleep schedule, also called cognitive behavioral therapy. Behavioral changes can be accomplished using programs like stimulus control therapy and sleep restriction therapy, done in conjunction with keeping daily sleep logs. It is important to prepare an ideal sleep environment internally and externally, and to maintain a regular bedtime and wake-up time as much as possible. Also, these programs stress the importance of getting out of bed if you are having trouble sleeping, instead of lying in bed worrying about not sleeping. Medications may be helpful as well, but best for short-term usage.

Sleep-breathing disorders include obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome (“OSA” for simplicity) among others. We focus on OSA since it is common and associated with many medical problems. OSA is caused by obstruction in the upper airway (nose to throat), usually at the base of the tongue. Obstruction of the upper airway cause decreases in airflow and therefore oxygen. Repeated episodes of obstruction are associated with medical problems like heart disease, memory loss, and increased risk for accidents. OSA is diagnosed with a sleep study, either in a laboratory setting or at home.

OSA may be treated in many different ways. Behavioral changes are helpful, like losing weight, side sleeping, and avoiding alcohol before bed. The medical “gold standard” is continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) which acts as a splint to open the airway. Other treatments include devices made by a dentist to stabilize the jaw and tongue in a more forward position, and a variety of surgeries aimed at different parts of the upper airway to create more space for air to flow. Newer treatments are being developed all the time, so find out more from your doctor or sleep specialist.

Daytime sleepiness is considered excessive when it interferes with daytime performance. Excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) may be medically significant if sleep occurs unintentionally during your usual waking hours. EDS is not the same a fatigue, which may include features such as loss of stamina, strength, or concentration. There are many possible causes of EDS, such as an underlying sleep problem, medications, or mood disorder like depression. The major health risk associated with EDS is an increased risk of accidents. The diagnosis of the underlying cause of EDS is made after a very thorough assessment by your doctor. The Epworth Sleepiness Scale is a common measure of daytime sleepiness. Additional tests will depend on your doctor’s assessment, but may include a sleep study.
Treatment of EDS is determined by the underlying cause(s). Close follow-up is needed to be sure your level of sleepiness improves with the treatment of the suspected cause(s).

The Pig is highly intelligent and symbolizes wealth and properity. The pig spirit warns us to shy away from ovberindulgence and slefishness, not to be addicted to material things so that we may grow spiritually instead.
The Deer signifies natural beauty and grace. The deer spirit acts in quick bursts of high energy, and shows us the value of play in enjoying life and our relationships.
The Sheep signifies the importance of self-reflection, taking the time to understand ourselves better so that we may succeed in creating our own uniques path.
The Fox represents change, shape-shifting, and suprise. The Fox appears in our dreams to spark our imagination and creativity.
The Penguin signifies adaptabilityu even in the face of chaos. The Penguin encourages us to control our emotions, find balance, and trust ourselves.

The Cow is nuturing and caring, and symbolizes fertility. The cow spirit reminds us to try to take a more docile approach to a situation at hand, yet to pay close attention to be sure we are not blindly following the lead to others.

The Chicken has great potential but tends to be distracted and prone to gossipe. The chicken spirit reminds us to focus and listen carefully, in order to accomplish the tasks we set out to accomplish.

The Dolphin represents the melding of the mind and spirit to highten our communication. The dolphin spirit challenges us to explore the depths of our own psyches in order to experience a spiritual awakening
The Rabbit symbolizes good luck, magic fertility, and abundance. The rabbit spirit reminds us to remain postimistic and to create joy and faithfulness in our relationships.
The Monkey is playful and lighthearted. The monkey spirit awakens out inner child, but warns us of false friendships with those that may want to take advantage of us.
The Lion is a powerful symbol of strength, courage, and leadership. The lion spirit gives us courage and helps us overcome obstacles, but also cautions us against the obstacle of our own pride.
The Tiger symbolizes good health, beauty, freedom, and vitality. The tiger spirit helps us release this energy to gather inner strength and self-confidence.
Ths Dog is a powerful friend and ally, sharing its gifts of loyalty, generosity, protection, and unconditional love. Knowing a dogs spirit givesb us confidence to go forward without hesitation.
The Zebra teaches us to look at things from different angles or viewpoints. The Zebra reminds us of the power of teamwork to acheive our goals, both for the individual and the group.
The Leopard symbolizes, patience nd persistence. The leopard spirit teaches us self-respect, acceptance, and perseverance.
The Panda symbolizes gentleness and gratitude, and in a dream is a reminder to seek solitude, and reflcet, and nourish yourself.
The Elephant symbolizes dignity, strength, and wisdom. The elephant spirit is healing and reminds us to be patient with others.

The Horse signifies power and strength. The horse spirit challenges the dreamer to achieve a higher sense of awareness and to surrender control to the horse and its power. The horse is then able to guide us on our individual path.
